questions.article:
The following text is adapted from John Matheus's 1925 short story Fog. A train has stopped at a station, where heavy fog has set in.

The little conductor stood on tiptoe in an effort to keep one hand on the signal rope, craning his neck in a vain and dissatisfied endeavor to pierce the miasma of the fog. The motorman chafed in his box, thinking of the drudging lot of the laboring man. He registered discontent.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word "registered" most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Bypassed

options.name: B
options.content: Enrolled

options.name: C
options.content: Valued

options.name: D
options.content: Displayed

questions.correct: Displayed

questions.article: As a member of Indigenous Photograph, artist Tshepiso Mabula ka Ndogngeni (Xhosa) can ______ her work more broadly than she could without the organization's reach. Photography editors around the world can search for Indigenous photographer members on the organization's website to find images that document and reflect the lives of Indigenous communities.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: empty

options.name: B
options.content: promote

options.name: C
options.content: alter

options.name: D
options.content: discover

questions.correct: promote

questions.article: Originating in the traditional stories of the Kanaka Maoli, the Native Hawaiian people, the literature of Hawaiʻi has a rich history that was later brought to international prominence by writers such as Mary Kawena Pukui. Now, by producing acclaimed works, Gary Pak has ______ his place in that literary tradition.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: contemplated

options.name: B
options.content: subverted

options.name: C
options.content: solidified

options.name: D
options.content: extricated

questions.correct: solidified

questions.article: In a 2018 article about films depicting the experiences of Black Americans, critics for the New York Times praise Madeline Anderson's 1970 film I Am Somebody as “galvanizing” and Reginald Hudlin’s 1990 film House Party as “exuberant.” Fans of the two films hope that such ______ will attract new audiences to these works.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: impartiality

options.name: B
options.content: ambivalence

options.name: C
options.content: foresight

options.name: D
options.content: acclaim

questions.correct: acclaim

questions.article: Researchers César A. Hidalgo, Elisa Castañer, and Andres Sevtsuk created a computer model to predict the mix of businesses and places of interest found in a given neighborhood. The team used data from the Google Places API service to help identify florists, beauty salons, and other businesses and map their locations. This approach has some limits—data from Places API tend to be restricted to places that are customer facing—but the data set nonetheless provides an extremely reliable source to study colocation patterns of neighborhood amenities.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It describes the imprecise and subjective nature of neighborhood boundaries.

options.name: B
options.content: It introduces a model that a research team built to evaluate the mix of amenities in urban neighborhoods.

options.name: C
options.content: It emphasizes the potential utility of the team's model.

options.name: D
options.content: It identifies a specific flaw in using a data set about amenities in cities.

questions.correct: It identifies a specific flaw in using a data set about amenities in cities.

questions.article: Known for the albums Someday My Prince Will Come and Milestones, jazz trumpeter Miles Davis collaborated several times with pianist Gil Evans. Their 1958 adaptation of George Gershwin's opera Porgy and Bess bears little resemblance to the 1935 original. Davis and Evans felt no desire to please listeners expecting an exact duplication of the opera. They omitted parts, such as the aria “I Got Plenty of Nuthin’,” and sometimes made only brief gestures toward Gershwin’s melodies. But Davis and Evans’s willingness to recompose Gershwin’s work led to one of the most enduring albums in Davis’s catalog.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It presents examples to support a claim made earlier in the text.

options.name: B
options.content: It shows how two artists benefited from ignoring certain conventions.

options.name: C
options.content: It proposes a reason why one work of art is widely thought to be more successful than another.

options.name: D
options.content: It undermines an assertion made later in the text.

questions.correct: It presents examples to support a claim made earlier in the text.

questions.article: Scholarly interest in literary juvenilia—writings by children and teenagers—tends to focus on unpublished works by authors who became famous as adults, such as W.H. Auden’s poem “Autumn,” which he wrote around age 15, because they offer insights into their authors’ artistic development. But some scholars also argue that recovering juvenilia by lesser-known writers is essential to understanding literary history: Daisy Ashford’s novels, which she published as a child, were widely read by contemporaries and are therefore deserving of closer attention.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To describe the challenges famous writers encountered when seeking to publish works written in their childhood

options.name: B
options.content: To argue that Ashford’s novels have more literary merit than Auden’s juvenilia do

options.name: C
options.content: To compare the accomplishments of young writers with those of their adult contemporaries

options.name: D
options.content: To present reasons why literary scholars consider juvenilia to be valuable resources

questions.correct: To present reasons why literary scholars consider juvenilia to be valuable resources

questions.article: Superlubricity, the state of virtually no friction between materials, has desirable applications in many industries. For example, it can make aircraft engines more efficient. To produce a coating that achieves superlubricity, Chanaka Kumara and colleagues broke down carbon nanotubes into fragments of graphene to fully cover two surfaces that would rub together. Friction between pieces of graphene is generally extremely low, and when the researchers added a drop of oil as lubrication, that friction nearly vanished. This new coating may drastically lower friction-related energy costs.
questions.question: According to the text, what happened when the researchers added oil to the surfaces covered in graphene fragments?

options.name: A
options.content: All the pieces of graphene collected on just one of the two surfaces.

options.name: B
options.content: The low amount of friction between the surfaces became even lower.

options.name: C
options.content: Carbon nanotubes on the surfaces fractured into smaller pieces.

options.name: D
options.content: Friction between the surfaces did not noticeably change right away.

questions.correct: The low amount of friction between the surfaces became even lower.

questions.article: Roy McLendon's Moonlit St. Lucie, a riverscape featuring the silhouette of a single palm tree against the backdrop of shimmering water and a brilliant moonlit sky, is typical of paintings by the Florida Highwaymen, an informal collective of landscape artists mainly active in the 1950s and ’60s. Remarkable for anticipating and amplifying cultural perceptions of Florida that became pervasive in the public consciousness, paintings by the Highwaymen are readily identifiable by the natural iconography—placid inland rivers, windswept palm trees—that McLendon and colleagues perpetually revisited.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Although similar in its subject matter to many paintings by the Florida Highwaymen, Moonlit St. Lucie is now more highly regarded than other Florida Highwaymen paintings are.

options.name: B
options.content: Representative images found across many paintings by McLendon and other Florida Highwaymen came to be widely associated with Florida in part due to the Florida Highwaymen’s influence.

options.name: C
options.content: Although paintings by the Florida Highwaymen were once celebrated for their depictions of Florida’s natural environments, the popularity of these paintings waned after the 1960s.

options.name: D
options.content: The placid inland rivers and windswept palm trees that are typical of McLendon’s works, which are otherwise indistinguishable from other Florida Highwaymen paintings, help to differentiate McLendon's paintings from those of his colleagues.

questions.correct: Representative images found across many paintings by McLendon and other Florida Highwaymen came to be widely associated with Florida in part due to the Florida Highwaymen’s influence.

questions.article:
The following text is from George Eliot's 1857 short story “The Sad Fortunes of the Rev. Amos Barton.” In the text, the narrator addresses the reader directly and alludes to a discussion among Rev. Amos Barton's neighbors.

It was happy for the Rev. Amos Barton that he did not, like us, overhear the conversation recorded in the last chapter. Indeed, what mortal is there of us, who would find his satisfaction enhanced by an opportunity of comparing the picture he presents to himself of his own doings, with the picture they make on the mental retina of his neighbours? We are poor plants buoyed up by the air-vessels of our own conceit: alas for us, if we get a few pinches that empty us of that windy self-subsistence! The very capacity for good would go out of us.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Although people grasp the importance of honesty, they typically resist confronting others about their flaws.

options.name: B
options.content: Although people wish to be seen as considerate, the slightest setbacks will often discourage them from being so.

options.name: C
options.content: People tend to fixate more often than they should on whether their acquaintances think highly of them.

options.name: D
options.content: People are better off not knowing about the discrepancy between their own self-image and what others think of them.

questions.correct: People are better off not knowing about the discrepancy between their own self-image and what others think of them.

questions.article: In a study of interactions between plants, researchers Carolina Laura Morales and Anna gathered data about flowering plants growing alongside each other in various. In each case, the researchers identified one plant as a “target species" and a plant as a "neighboring species." An example of a neighboring species is the musk which grows alongside the Peruvian lily in ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the example?

options.name: A
options.content: the United States.

options.name: B
options.content: Japan.

options.name: C
options.content: the United Kingdom.

options.name: D
options.content: Argentina.

questions.correct: Argentina.

questions.article: Drosophila (fruit flies) have generation times of 10-12 days, so seasonal changes in humidity and other environmental conditions can drive seasonal fluctuations in chromosome rearrangements in species such as D. persimilis and D. mediopunctata. Drosophila body size (for which wing centroid size serves as a proxy measure) correlates with life span. Banu Sebnem Önder and Cansu Fidan Aksoy measured the wing sizes of members of a D. melanogaster population in Yesilöz, Turkey, that were collected monthly between May and October over three years. Their research suggests that Drosophila collected in relatively warmer months should tend to have a longer life span, as is illustrated by the finding that ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the assertion?

options.name: A
options.content: the average monthly low temperature was higher in June than in May.

options.name: B
options.content: the average male wing centroid size was larger in July than in October.

options.name: C
options.content: the average female wing centroid size was 2.02 mm in July but was 2.31 mm in June.

options.name: D
options.content: the average female wing centroid size was consistently larger than the average male wing centroid size in all four months in the table.

questions.correct: the average male wing centroid size was larger in July than in October.

questions.article: A road was recently built in a Maryland woodland that is home to the house finch. Some finches’ nests were situated close to the new road and others were deeper in the woodland. Common ravens, which eat finch eggs, can spot nests near the open spaces of roads more easily than they can spot nests surrounded by woodland. Accordingly, researchers in Maryland trying to predict the impact of the new road on finches have suggested that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: finch eggs will make up about the same percentage of common ravens’ diet as they did before the road was built.

options.name: B
options.content: the number of finches building nests near the road will gradually increase as the finches adapt to the presence of the common ravens.

options.name: C
options.content: finches nesting near the road will lose eggs to common ravens at a higher rate than will finches nesting far from the road.

options.name: D
options.content: finches nesting far from the road will lay fewer eggs per nest than will finches nesting near the road.

questions.correct: finches nesting near the road will lose eggs to common ravens at a higher rate than will finches nesting far from the road.

questions.article: Biologists Rebecca M. Calisi-Rodriguez and George E. Bentley examined research on species such as dark-eyed juncos and tucos, which have both been studied under laboratory conditions as well as in the wild, to see whether there were significant differences between findings in the wild and in the lab. And, for example, they found for tucos that daytime is the most active period for wild individuals but not for captive individuals. Calisi-Rodriguez and Bentley therefore concluded that the laboratory setting was likely ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: more suitable than wild settings for studying tucos’ patterns of rest and activity.

options.name: B
options.content: affecting the results for both tucos and dark-eyed juncos.

options.name: C
options.content: more suitable for studying dark-eyed juncos than for studying tucos.

options.name: D
options.content: interfering with tucos’ patterns of rest and activity.

questions.correct: interfering with tucos’ patterns of rest and activity.

questions.article: All stainless steel contains varying amounts of iron, carbon, and corrosion-inhibiting chromium. However, ferritic stainless steel, often used for induction cookers, contains a higher percentage of chromium (at least 10.5%) than does austenitic stainless steel as well as a higher concentration of iron. Unlike ferritic stainless steel, austenitic stainless steel has a face-centered cubic crystalline structure held stable by the presence of nickel and nitrogen. Austenitic stainless steel has two subtypes: the 200 series, often used for washing machines, and the 300 series, which has more nickel than the 200 series and is often used for storage containers or furnaces. Thus, stainless steel used to manufacture ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: furnaces and stainless steel used to manufacture washing machines will both have a chromium content of less than 10.5%.

options.name: B
options.content: washing machines will have a higher concentration of nickel in its composition than stainless steel used to manufacture furnaces will.

options.name: C
options.content: induction cookers will have a face-centered cubic crystalline structure, but stainless steel used to manufacture storage containers will not.

options.name: D
options.content: storage containers and stainless steel used to manufacture induction cookers will have a similar concentration of nitrogen in their compositions.

questions.correct: furnaces and stainless steel used to manufacture washing machines will both have a chromium content of less than 10.5%.

questions.article: An emulsifier is a type of compound that serves to stabilize an emulsion—a mixture of two or more liquids that otherwise would not easily blend together. In the cosmetics industry, emulsifiers such as stearyl alcohol ______ to blend oil and water into homogeneous formulations, like lotions and perfumes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: employed

options.name: B
options.content: being employed

options.name: C
options.content: are employed

options.name: D
options.content: that they employ

questions.correct: are employed

questions.article: The Akhundov National Library in Baku houses many historical newspapers, but it isn’t necessary to travel to Baku to access them. Because these rare items are digitized, people around the world can access ______ regardless of where they live.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: it

options.name: B
options.content: them

options.name: C
options.content: this

options.name: D
options.content: that

questions.correct: them

questions.article: The constitution of Spain, enacted in 1978, enshrines 60 total rights across 17,608 words of text. According to constitutional scholar George Tsebelis, who examines the implications of constitutional length on civil rights, ______ 105th in a global ranking of the shortest constitutions.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: its

options.name: B
options.content: it’s

options.name: C
options.content: they're

options.name: D
options.content: their

questions.correct: it’s

questions.article: Featuring works by the photographers Liselotte Grschebina and Else “Yva” Neuländer-Simon, the 2021 exhibition The New Woman Behind the Camera set out to provide a wide-ranging overview of photography by women in the 1920s through the ______ given the collection’s breadth of more than 120 photos, its efforts were largely successful.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: C
options.content: 1950s and

options.name: D
options.content: 1950s, and

questions.correct: 1950s, and

questions.article: The Austronesian language family comprises some 1,200 languages—including the ______ Javanese and Bikol, which are spoken by 100 million and 4.6 million speakers, respectively—and accounts for one-fifth of the world’s languages, making it of keen interest to linguists like Li Jen-kuei.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: languages

options.name: B
options.content: languages:

options.name: C
options.content: languages—

options.name: D
options.content: languages,

questions.correct: languages

questions.article: Blair L.M. Kelley, a historian specializing in the history of segregation in the US, conducted extensive research while writing a book about the landmark Brown v. Board of Education court case. ______ when the book was released, colleagues in her field regarded it as a reliable source of information on the subject.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Likewise,

options.name: B
options.content: Consequently,

options.name: C
options.content: Next,

options.name: D
options.content: Nevertheless,

questions.correct: Consequently,

questions.article: Many English adjectives share a linguistic origin with their associated nouns, like the adjective “monetary” and the noun “money,” both of which come from the Latin monetarius. ______ some adjectives do not share an origin with their associated nouns. For example, the adjective “bovine” ultimately comes from the Latin bos, while its associated noun, “cow,” comes from the Old English cù.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Subsequently,

options.name: B
options.content: For this reason,

options.name: C
options.content: Nevertheless,

options.name: D
options.content: Specifically,

questions.correct: Nevertheless,

questions.article: The decades since the Second World War have seen a range of outcomes for the independence movements of Micronesia, Melanesia, and Polynesia. Many of the regions’ islands and groups of islands have become independent nations. ______ the Northern Mariana Islands, a commonwealth in Micronesia consisting of fifteen islands, are part of the US, and the Society Islands, a group of islands in Polynesia including Tahiti and Bora Bora, are part of the territory of French Polynesia.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For example,

options.name: B
options.content: Therefore,

options.name: C
options.content: In fact,

options.name: D
options.content: On the other hand,

questions.correct: On the other hand,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A supercontinent is a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth’s continents.
  • Over time, continents merge together to form supercontinents, which then break apart.
  • This process is believed to take hundreds of millions of years and is known as the supercontinent cycle.
  • Ur was a supercontinent that formed about 3.1 billion years ago.
  • Euramerica was a supercontinent that formed about 300 million years ago.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a difference between the two supercontinents. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Euramerica formed about 300 million years ago, but Ur formed much earlier—about 3.1 billion years ago.

options.name: B
options.content: Forming and breaking apart over hundreds of millions of years, supercontinents are made up of most or all of Earth’s continents.

options.name: C
options.content: Ur and Euramerica were both supercontinents, single landmasses made up of most or all of Earth's continents.

options.name: D
options.content: Ur formed about 3.1 billion years ago but eventually broke apart.

questions.correct: Euramerica formed about 300 million years ago, but Ur formed much earlier—about 3.1 billion years ago.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Ixmiquilpan is a municipality in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico.
  • Municipalities are governmental regions responsible for providing many public services to their residents.
  • One service they provide is water treatment.
  • Ixmiquilpan’s population was 98,654 in 2020.
  • Hidalgo is divided into 84 municipalities.
questions.question: The student wants to provide an example of a public service that Ixmiquilpan is responsible for. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: As a municipality, Ixmiquilpan is responsible for providing water treatment to its residents.

options.name: B
options.content: Ixmiquilpan is one of 84 municipalities in Hidalgo providing public services to their communities.

options.name: C
options.content: Ixmiquilpan—a governmental region in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico—provides public services to its residents.

options.name: D
options.content: In 2020, the municipality of Ixmiquilpan had a population of 98,654.

questions.correct: As a municipality, Ixmiquilpan is responsible for providing water treatment to its residents.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Square Tower House is a former Ancestral Puebloan settlement in southwestern Colorado that was inhabited from approximately 1200–1300 CE.
  • It contained elaborate multistory buildings primarily made of adobe and stone.
  • The Ancestral Puebloan civilization (approximately 1200 BCE–1600 CE) was the precursor of modern Pueblo tribal nations.
  • These modern nations include Zuni Pueblo and Isleta Pueblo.
  • Buildings in Zuni Pueblo and Isleta Pueblo often incorporate traditional elements, such as adobe and stone, alongside more contemporary elements.
questions.question: The student wants to connect Square Tower House to modern-day Pueblo buildings. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Modern-day Pueblo buildings, such as those in Zuni Pueblo and Isleta Pueblo, incorporate elements that wouldn't have been found in Square Tower House.

options.name: B
options.content: The Ancestral Puebloan settlement of Square Tower House was built with adobe and stone, materials still used in the buildings of Zuni Pueblo and Isleta Pueblo.

options.name: C
options.content: The elaborate buildings of Square Tower House in southwestern Colorado incorporate both traditional and modern-day elements in their design.

options.name: D
options.content: Square Tower House, located in southwestern Colorado, was inhabited from approximately 1200–1300 CE, but its buildings aren’t actively occupied today.

questions.correct: The Ancestral Puebloan settlement of Square Tower House was built with adobe and stone, materials still used in the buildings of Zuni Pueblo and Isleta Pueblo.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Element abundance is a relative measure of the occurrence of a chemical element in a given environment.
  • An element’s relative abundance can be expressed as a mass fraction, mole fraction, or volume fraction.
  • Mass fraction is the ratio of an element’s mass to the combined mass of all elements in a given environment.
  • The mass fraction of calcium (Ca) is 17,100 parts per million (ppm), or 1.71%, on Earth.
  • The mass fraction of potassium (K) is 160 ppm, or 0.016%, on Earth.
questions.question: The student wants to specify an element's relative abundance on Earth. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Mass fraction, mole fraction, and volume fraction can all be used to express an element's relative abundance in a given environment.

options.name: B
options.content: Expressed as a mass fraction, the relative abundance of potassium on Earth is 160 ppm, or 0.016%.

options.name: C
options.content: The relative abundance of the element potassium on Earth can be expressed in three different ways.

options.name: D
options.content: On Earth, the mass fraction of potassium is greater than that of calcium.

questions.correct: Expressed as a mass fraction, the relative abundance of potassium on Earth is 160 ppm, or 0.016%.
